cycle_6_headline: Counter-Signal Revolution: First cycle with serious counter-evidence. 2 opportunities killed, 1 parked. Kill index populated for the first time. Engine maturity inflection — now optimizing for WHERE to enter, not just WHAT to disrupt.

top_opportunities.name: Construction AI Coordinator — Filling the Immigration Labor Gap
top_opportunities.thesis: 92% of contractors struggling to hire. Immigration enforcement removing 25%+ of workforce. AI can't lay bricks but CAN do project management, estimation, permit compliance, scheduling, safety monitoring, and supplier coordination — 30-40% of project costs. Multiply each remaining foreman's capacity by 3-5x.
key_data: 92% of contractors struggling with labor shortages (AGC Survey)
Construction one of few sectors where AI augments rather than replaces
No major counter-signals yet — needs competitive scan in Cycle 7
top_opportunities.vc_hook: Immigration policy just permanently removed a quarter of the construction workforce. We're not bringing them back — we're making the remaining workers do 3x the work.
top_opportunities.status: scanning — priority for Cycle 7 competitive scan

top_opportunities.name: PE Roll-Up Disruptor — Pure Agentic vs Acquire-and-Restructure
top_opportunities.thesis: PE firms spending $50M-$500M to buy and fix what AI-native entrants can beat from scratch at $500K. 147 PE deals in accounting alone, leveraged and assuming stable client retention. When AI disruption accelerates beyond their restructuring capacity, PE roll-ups become the distressed assets. Position against the PE roll-up wave.
key_data: 147 PE deals in accounting, $200B new value created
Crete $500M+, Ascend $314M revenue, Accrual $75M — all leveraged bets on restructuring
PE roll-ups may face Minsky moment if AI disruption outpaces their integration capacity
top_opportunities.vc_hook: PE firms are spending $50M to buy and fix what we can beat from scratch for $500K. Their thesis requires restructuring; ours requires a laptop.
top_opportunities.status: scanning — H2 timing, monitor PE roll-up health
top_opportunities.counter_signal_status: Needs dedicated scan — could face same crowding issue

top_opportunities.name: Distressed Professional Services Acquisition + Agentic Rebuild
top_opportunities.thesis: PARKED: Thesis structurally valid but competitive landscape untenable at $500K-$1M. Crete ($500M+), Accrual ($75M), Ascend ($314M revenue), and 147 PE deals have saturated the entry window. May reopen if PE roll-ups face Minsky distress or if LATAM/niche sub-sectors scanned.
top_opportunities.park_reason: Competitive landscape saturated with $500M+ capital. Thesis correct but entry at $500K-$1M not viable in core US market.
reactivation_triggers: PE roll-up Minsky moment — signs of distress in Crete/Ascend/Accrual
LATAM professional services showing same cascade with less PE competition
Niche sub-sector identified (veterinary, surveying, translation) with no PE presence

top_opportunities.name: Healthcare Staffing Gap — AI-Augmented Nurse Capacity Multiplier
top_opportunities.thesis: KILLED: Federal legislation (H.R. 3415 / S. 1709) explicitly prohibits technology as nurse staffing substitute in ratio calculations. Core value proposition is illegal.
top_opportunities.kill_reason: Nurse ratio manipulation illegal under pending federal and active state law. NNU running national anti-AI campaign. 80-99% false alarm rates. Olive AI ($1B) failed. Epic building competing solutions from 42% market share.

top_opportunities.name: Agentic Back-Office for Distressed SMBs
top_opportunities.thesis: KILLED: Bench.co ($113M) built exactly this and catastrophically failed. Intuit (80%+ share, $100M OpenAI deal) is the AI winner, not the victim. Pilot ($325M) achieved 0.4% penetration.
top_opportunities.kill_reason: Incumbent moat (Intuit 80%+ with $100M OpenAI partnership) + proven startup failure pattern (Bench $113M fail, Pilot $325M for 0.4%) + behavioral adoption resistance (70% on paper after 43 years).

entries.reason: Federal law explicitly blocks core value proposition
Incumbent moat (Intuit) + proven failure pattern (Bench, Pilot)

transmission_chains.status: Fully materialized but entry window crowded
Chain blocked at N5 by federal legislation

transmission_chains.chain: P7 Timing Arbitrage — Premature Human Cuts

transmission_chains.status: Needs competitive scan and counter-signal research

LATAM.note: Not yet scanned — priority for Cycle 7

cross_principle_patterns.evidence: Prof services -97K jobs while healthcare +709K. Same economy, opposite directions.
C&I loans down $55.8B while delinquency stable. Incumbents denied restructuring capital.
1000x inference cost reduction makes $37/hr human labor look like 37-370x overpay for many tasks.
HY spread 2.87% (tight) while Ch.11 +76% YoY. Market mispricing = timing window.
Companies cutting human capacity before AI can deliver, creating service vacuums. HBR documents pattern. 55K AI-cited layoffs.

cycle_history.note: Counter-signal revolution. First kills. Top score dropped from 87→65 as inflated opportunities corrected.

master_synthesis: Cycle 6 is the engine's maturity inflection point. The counter-signal research did exactly what it was designed to do: stress-tested our top 3 opportunities against reality and found 2 fatally flawed and 1 competitively untenable. This is not a failure — this is the engine working correctly. The Principles Engine successfully identified WHERE disruption is happening (professional services cascade, healthcare shortage, SMB overhead crisis). What it did not capture — and what Cycle 6 corrects — is the competitive landscape and regulatory environment that determine whether WE can be the disruptors. The kill index is now populated with 2 entries, both carrying a critical lesson: the PROBLEM is always valid when the Principles Engine flags it, but the SOLUTION must be tested against who else has already seen the same opportunity. Cycle 7 must apply the proven analytical framework to sectors where PE and well-funded startups have NOT yet arrived. The strongest remaining signals are Construction AI Coordinator (untested for competitive density) and the P7 Timing Arbitrage pattern (confirmed but needs sector-level identification). The framework works — we just need to point it at less crowded terrain.
